cards.title: Tottenham / Lloris may miss start of season with fractured wrist
cards.rawTitle: Lloris may miss start of season with fractured wrist

item.title: Tottenham’s Hugo Lloris fractures wrist and may miss start of season
item.trailText: Tottenham’s goalkeeper Hugo Lloris has suffered a fractured wrist during the close season and could miss the start of the new campaign
item.standFirst:
• Goalkeeper able to work on fitness with first-team squad
• France international linked with move to Manchester United
item.body:
Tottenham Hotspur have been dealt a potentially serious blow after Hugo Lloris reported back for pre-season training hampered by a wrist injury and scans confirmed a fracture that could rule out the France goalkeeper for the start of the campaign.

Lloris, who earned his 66th and 67th caps in Les Bleus’ friendly defeats to Belgium and Albania last month, returned to Spurs on Monday but, once his wrist had been examined, left the club’s Enfield base wearing a splint on the joint. Rehabilitation for fractures can be up to eight weeks. Tottenham begin their Premier League campaign at Manchester United on 8 August.

The club released a statement confirming the injury. “The France goalkeeper will continue to work alongside the first-team squad to build up his fitness in a bid to be ready for the start of the season,” Tottenham said. “Our medical team will continue to monitor his rehabilitation and progress during pre-season.”

Lloris, who was recruited from Lyon for £8m in 2012, is Tottenham’s first-choice goalkeeper and signed a new contract last summer on improved terms to run through to 2019. However, the Frenchman admitted last month that there comes a time “to think about yourself” when it became clear David de Gea’s future at United was in doubt after Real Madrid declared an interest in luring the goalkeeper back to the Spanish capital.

The 28-year-old Lloris has long made it clear to the Spurs chairman, Daniel Levy, he is anxious to play in the Champions League, where he had featured in each of his four years with his previous side, particularly before Euro 2016 in his homeland. Yet the France captain’s time at White Hart Lane has failed to yield a return to Europe’s elite competition and a fifth-place finish last season ensured the Europa League awaits yet again.“You don’t know what could happen,” said Lloris in an interview with L’Equipe. “There is one important thing: there is a moment to think about yourself, to sit down and reflect, but when that moment has passed and the season starts, you’re fully committed to the club’s project and to the team (you’re with).” Asked if that moment to reflect had now come, he added: “Voilà. But you don’t control everything.”

Spurs are adamant that one of their most consistent players over recent seasons is not available for transfer. Should Lloris be unavailable at the start of the Premier League campaign, they will turn to Michel Vorm, who made only four top-flight appearances for the London club last season following his £5m arrival from Swansea City.

cards.title: QPR / Club to earn record fee from Sterling sell-on clause
cards.rawTitle: Club to earn record fee from Sterling sell-on clause

item.title: QPR earn record fee from Raheem Sterling’s move through sell-on clause
item.trailText: Queens Park Rangers are set to earn what will be, in effect, their record incoming fee in the wake of Liverpool’s sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City
item.standFirst:
• Forward was developed at QPR’s academy before move to Liverpool in 2010
• Deal included 20% sell-on clause on any profit from subsequent sale
• Sterling has the talent but Manchester City need to see it every week
item.body:
Queens Park Rangers are set to earn what will, in effect, be their record incoming fee in the wake of Liverpool’s sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City courtesy of a clause inserted into the deal which took the young player from Loftus Road to Anfield five years ago.

Sterling, who was born in Jamaica and moved to London at the age of seven, was developed at QPR’s academy before Liverpool prised him away in February 2010 for an initial £600,000. That fee had the potential to rise as high as £5m because it was linked to appearances made in the first team and honours secured.

Related: Manchester City and Liverpool agree £49m fee for Raheem Sterling

While the 129 games played by Sterling, now 20, for Liverpool are unlikely to have maximised those add-ons, there was also a 20% sell-on clause included in the agreement on any profit from a subsequent sale.

The precise fees and commitments that have been and will be met by Liverpool to QPR are confidential but, given the England international is costing City £44m with a further £5m linked to honours and appearances, QPR, relegated from the Premier League in May, will bank a minimum of £7.8m from his switch to Manchester.

In reality that figure is likely to be significantly higher. QPR’s biggest previous sales have been Christopher Samba, at £12m, and Loïc Rémy, at around £8m, to Anzhi Makhachkala and Chelsea respectively but neither of those deals secured a profit for the club because of the fees that had brought them to Loftus Road.

Related: Liverpool’s Brendan Rodgers confirms Raheem Sterling exit but denies rift with player

The money from Sterling’s move could yet be eclipsed by the sale of Charlie Austin this summer. QPR are holding out for £15m for the England squad player who has entered the final 12 months of his contract.

The club’s lawyers are still in dialogue with the Football League challenging the governing body’s financial fair play rules but are confident the threat of a potential £58m fine – a legacy of their promotion-winning campaign of 2013-14 – will be warded off.

cards.title: Boca Juniors / Tevez says he wants to write history after returning home
cards.rawTitle: Tevez says he wants to write history after returning home

item.title: Carlos Tevez says he wants to write history after returning to Boca Juniors
item.trailText: Carlos Tevez has been officially unveiled as a Boca Juniors player in a £4.6m (6.5 million euro) transfer from Juventus
item.standFirst:
• Tevez joins for £4.6m while Juve secure Guido Vadalá on loan
“I’m returning in my prime … At 26 or 27 I was fatter than anyone’
item.body:
Carlos Tevez has been officially unveiled as a Boca Juniors player in a £4.6m (6.5 million euro) transfer from Juventus.

Thousands of fans packed La Bombonera to welcome Tevez home from a decade abroad the day after the team went top of the Argentine league championship.

“My heart’s exploding with happiness! Thanks for braving the cold and waiting for me. I’m already back home,” Tevez said on Twitter.

Juventus, the last club of Tevez’s overseas spell, that began at Corinthians in Brazil in 2005 and included English sides West Ham United, Manchester United and Manchester City, revealed the terms of the deal on their website.

On top of the fee for Tevez, the Italian champions have acquired the Boca teenager Guido Vadalá on loan until June 2017 with an option to buy him for £6.7m (9.4 million euros) as well as first refusal on three other young players.

“I’m returning in my prime, really that’s now. At 26 or 27 I was fatter than anyone. I feel better than ever, physically and mentally,” the 31-year-old said.

Tevez will wear the No10 shirt previously worn by Diego Maradona and Juan Román Riquelme.

“Riquelme is one of the greatest, an idol of the club,” Tevez said. “I’m not here to better him, I’m here to write my own history.”

Related: Lionel Messi and Argentina losing sleep as Uruguay loom at Copa América 2015 | Jonathan Wilson

Boca went top of the table with a 1-0 win at Sarmiento on Sunday, a point ahead of San Lorenzo and three in front of River Plate. Tevez, who missed the resumption of the championship because he was on holiday after playing for Argentina at the Copa América, said he would train all week to be ready for his comeback in next weekend’s home match against Quilmes.

San Lorenzo drew 1-1 at Union and River were also held 1-1 by Temperley at El Monumental as they rested first choice players for Tuesday’s first leg of their Libertadores Cup semi-final against Guarani of Paraguay.

Sunday was also a good day for the former Argentina defender Gabriel Heinze, who made his coaching debut with Godoy Cruz in a 3-0 home win over Crucero del Norte in Mendoza.

cards.title: Man Utd / Cavani first choice to replace Van Persie
cards.rawTitle: Cavani first choice to replace Van Persie

item.title: Manchester United identify Edinson Cavani as Robin van Persie replacement
item.trailText: Edinson Cavani is Louis van Gaal’s No1 choice to fill the vacancy left by Robin van Persie who will complete his move from Manchester United to Fenerbahce on Monday
item.standFirst:
• Move for Uruguayan striker may include Ángel Di María as makeweight
• United to rubber stamp Morgan Schneiderlin signing on Monday
item.body:
Edinson Cavani is Louis van Gaal’s No1 choice to fill the vacancy left by Robin van Persie, who will complete his move from Manchester United to Fenerbahce on Monday. Any prospective deal for Paris Saint-Germain’s Cavani may involve Ángel Di María going the other way as the French club want the Argentinian and Van Gaal is considering allowing him to go.

The departure of Van Persie, who should be unveiled at Fenerbahce’s stadium on Monday, leaves Wayne Rooney as the only recognised goalscorer at Old Trafford. PSG’s Cavani has been a long-term target for United’s manager who is strengthening his squad in the current transfer window.

Related: Manchester United get Southampton’s Morgan Schneiderlin for £24m

In central midfield Bastian Schweinsteiger has been signed from Bayern Munich and he is expected to be followed by Southampton’s Morgan Schneiderlin on Monday. Each should be part of the United squad that flies to Seattle on Monday afternoon to start the summer tour of the US. The Italy right-back Matteo Darmian has already been signed and, along with Van Gaal’s first close-season acquisition Memphis Depay, will be on the plane for the four-match trip that represents United’s sole competitive football before Tottenham Hotspur arrive at Old Trafford on 8 August for the start of the season.

The targeting of Cavani underlines how Van Gaal is seeking to add elite players in his bid to hit the ground running when the new campaign commences. Di María had an uneven first season at United following his British record £59.7m arrival last summer. Van Gaal is open to letting the winger leave if he can be a makeweight in acquiring Cavani.

The goalkeeper David De Gea could still miss the trip to the US after Iker Casillas left Real Madrid for Porto at the weekend.

If a deal for De Gea were to involve Sergio Ramos coming the other way from Real, the goalkeeper may not take the flight to Seattle. Ramos, meanwhile, would be another elite player landed by Van Gaal.

If Cavani and Ramos could be added then Van Gaal would have only the goalkeeper position to address this summer. Víctor Valdés, who is already at United, is one option.

cards.title: Real Madrid try to repair Iker Casillas damage – but only make things worse
cards.rawTitle: Real Madrid try to repair Iker Casillas damage – but only make things worse

item.title: Real Madrid try to repair Iker Casillas damage – but only make things worse
item.trailText: Two thousand people turned up for Iker Casillas’ second goodbye in 25 hours – but they were mainly interested in heckling Florentino Pérez over the goalkeeper and the possible sale of Sergio Ramos to Manchester United
item.standFirst: Two thousand people turned up for Iker Casillas’ second goodbye in 25 hours – but they were mainly interested in heckling Florentino Pérez
item.body:
Let’s try again, shall we? Twenty-five hours after departing Real Madrid alone, Iker Casillas was back at the Santiago Bernabéu to say goodbye for a second time. On Sunday at 12pm it had been the press room, on Monday at 1pm, the stage was set in the directors’ suite and the club president Florentino Pérez did attend along with his board, who stood to applaud. There were fans too, around 2,000 of them waiting in the sunshine, where a platform had been built on the pitch adorned with the trophies Casillas won during a 17-year career here.

Related: No fanfare for Real Madrid legend Iker Casillas as he leaves for Porto

Casillas appeared and they chanted his name as he made his way, first towards the trophies and then towards them. But, while their numbers were relatively small with this act held before lunchtime on a working day, probably more significant were the other chants: “Sergio Ramos is not for sale!” directed not so much at Manchester United as at Pérez, and “Florentino, resign!” This was not really a fond farewell for Casillas and nor did it do that much to repair the damage done a day before. It may even have made it worse.

History repeats itself, first as tragedy, second as farce. After 48 hours in which Casillas’s departure was on then off, then on then off again, came 24 hours in which he publicly “left” twice. Another day, another goodbye. This was an odd and sometimes uncomfortable occasion, much of it conducted in Orwellian Newspeak, as if Sunday never happened and yet all was about Sunday. When the former captain stood up to speak, he smiled awkwardly. “This one really is the last one, eh,” he said.

__VIDEO_EMBED_gu-video-457483097__

Casillas spoke for a few seconds and had not prepared anything. Nor did he face any questions; it was the president who held a press conference, not him. “As we were saying,” the new Porto goalkeeper offered, almost by way of excuse. “If there has been any discrepancy, I am sorry,” he added. “We’ll remember the good moments.”

By then Pérez had spoken; now Pérez spoke again. Casillas sat down and listened in silence as everybody talked about him. Pérez took the lectern again and took questions, almost as if Casillas were not there. This wasn’t about him; this first part of the event, before he headed out to the pitch where the trophies and the fans awaited him, was not much of a goodbye.

Instead, it was a presidential defence, an opportunity for Pérez to justify himself – Madrid had helped Casillas leave, not forced him to – and to challenge the good guy/bad guy narrative. When the goalkeeper later stepped into the sunshine, without Pérez, and the fans received him with cheers and the president with calls to resign, it appeared that the task may have been necessary but may not be easy.

“I had always planned to hold this press conference, only without Iker,” Pérez claimed, and he might as well have done. “But I wanted Iker, our great captain, to be here,” he said. The doubt was why Casillas had agreed, why he sat there in silence, almost invisible.

“What had changed since yesterday?” Pérez was asked. “Nothing,” he said and yet at the same time he did admit that he had called Casillas in “so that people don’t think that there is anything strange,” adding: “I have affection for him, despite what people want to see.” There were indeed warm words, even if the sincerity of the sentiment is another question, with the president describing Casillas as “the best goalkeeper in Spanish football history” and as a “magnificent human being”, noting: “we love him, respect him, and admire him.”

But the key focus, reinforced as the press conference went on, was to counteract reports that his relationship with the captain had been strained or that he had forced Casillas out, starting with Sunday’s original departure. “Iker wanted an extremely austere, simple goodbye and we accepted that even though we didn’t want it,” Pérez claimed. And, besides, he added: the club is working on a friendly against Porto to be played “as soon as possible”.

“Iker is leaving because he wanted to, and we can only respect that wish because he earned that right,” Pérez continued. “No one asked him to leave. A few days ago he got an offer from Porto and he asked us to consider it. We did that. He has earned the right for the club to make an effort on his behalf.”

Pérez also called Casillas “irreplaceable” although he aspires to replace him with David De Gea. All the while, Casillas sat in the front row, listening as Pérez claimed to have “always defended” him, that he wanted the goalkeeper to “retire at the club”, that he would have liked him to stay, and that he found it “incomprehensible” and “unacceptable” that some supporters whistled him. “The door will always be open for Casillas,” Pérez said. It has been open for some time.

cards.title: Grimsby / Fan guilty of assaulting steward with inflatable shark
cards.rawTitle: Fan guilty of assaulting steward with inflatable shark

item.title: Grimsby fan guilty of assaulting Barnet steward with inflatable shark
item.trailText: Grimsby Town supporter Kenneth Meech was found guilty of assaulting a steward with an inflatable shark at a Conference match at Barnet
item.standFirst:
• Kenneth Meech found guilty of common assault after February match
• Given 12-month conditional discharge and ordered to pay steward £100
item.body:
A Grimsby Town supporter was found guilty on Monday of assaulting a steward with an inflatable shark at a Conference match.

Kenneth Meech, 50, told the BBC he took the blow-up toy fish to the fifth-tier clash at Barnet in February in support of a fellow fan who had been ejected from an earlier away game for refusing to hand over a large beach ball.

Related: Sacha Baron Cohen angers residents of Grimsby and Tilbury

“A lot of lads were saying, ‘Come on, let’s get together and support Bryan’ by taking as many inflatables as possible to Barnet and that’s what we did, because we’ve got a good sense of humour,” Meech said. Grimsby won 3-1 after a late winner.

“We were jumping about amongst each other, celebrating, and before I knew it – I was shocked really – I was grabbed out by the police and taken away.“

Magistrates at Willesden in north London convicted Meech of common assault with a 12-month conditional discharge. He was also ordered to pay the steward £100 in compensation.

cards.title: Liverpool / Rodgers denies Sterling rift and confirms player’s exit
cards.rawTitle: Rodgers denies Sterling rift and confirms player’s exit

item.title: Liverpool’s Brendan Rodgers confirms Raheem Sterling exit but denies rift with player
item.trailText: Brendan Rodgers has confirmed Raheem Sterling will join Manchester City from Liverpool subject to a medical, insisting he has no personal issue with the 20-year-old player
item.standFirst:
• Rodgers admits Sterling will join City subject to medical
• Liverpool manager denies falling out with 20-year-old winger
item.body:
Brendan Rodgers has confirmed Raheem Sterling will join Manchester City from Liverpool subject to a medical, insisting he has no personal issue with the 20-year-old player.

Rodgers, speaking at a news conference in Thailand where Liverpool are kicking off their pre-season tour of Asia and Australia, did not provide specific details of the reported £49m transfer but confirmed an agreement had been reached.

Related: Manchester City and Liverpool agree £49m fee for Raheem Sterling

“The situation is very simple. The club has agreed with another for a deal for Raheem to be transferred and subject to medical that will go through,” Rodgers said. “Contrary to the last week or so, in terms of what was written, Raheem and I have always remained very strong in our relationship, and have been up until he left. There’s no issue there.”

Manchester City had two bids for Sterling rejected last month after he turned down the offer of a pay increase to stay at Anfield. Sterling did not fly out with Liverpool for their pre-season tour despite being named in the squad.

Rodgers was coy about the details, saying he was focusing on the players on the tour.

“I spoke to Raheem at length yesterday, there is no issue. Two clubs have agreed a deal and subject to a medical he will move on,” Rodgers said. “It’s important for us to improve and build the squad for this season coming. We are pleased with the players we have brought in. It’s the overall team that is important. We aim to be stronger than last season that will be reliant on everyone.”
